Event Handling


LexGUI relies almost entirely on callbacks when creating each of its widgets and it's not a problem when a callback should be triggered only from one place.

Signals

For those cases where there is no trivial connection between the callbacks and the element that triggers it, LexGUI allows to create Signals. E.g. We could make a widget to be updated when it receives a signal from any location in the application.

Connect a Signal

The following code is creating a widget bound to a signal. That implies that it will be updated when it receives the corresponding signal:

panel.addNumber("Font Size", 36, (value, event) => {
    console.log(value);
}, { signal: "@on_set_fontsize", min: 1, max: 48 });

In the case the receiver it's not a widget we could do it using LX.addSignal(name, obj, callback):

LX.addSignal( "@on_value_changed", element, function(value) {
    console.log(value);
} );
Note that we are using a callback this time that will called within the element scope when the signal is emitted.

Emit a Signal

To emit a signal we only have to call LX.emit(signal_name, value, target) in any of the cases, where target is optional. If defined, the callback will be called only to that object.
